column3: US v Phua, 14-cr-00249, US District Court, District of Nevada (Las Vegas).
column4: U.S. prosecutors’ assertions that Paul Phua is a member or leader of the Chinese organized crime group called the 14K Triad.
column5: The judge last week threw out the evidence obtained from searches of two other villas the group used because a warrant was based on the earlier illegal entry to Phua’s suite. The defense argued that Phua had been in the rooms at the Wynn Macau by chance, arriving for a meeting on a potential business project just minutes before the police raid. The judge said the Public Prosecution Office had failed to prove that the computers and papers seized from the rooms — which contained information on bets on soccer matches — belonged to the defendants. Moreover, police were unable to provide any evidence linking Phua’s phone or computer records to illegal betting activity. On delivering his verdict, the judge said the Public Prosecution Office had failed to prove that the computers and papers seized from the rooms belonged to the defendants. On Tuesday, one of the lawyers that had defended Phua in Las Vegas and had advised his legal team in Macau, Tom Goldstein, told the Macau News Agency that he was grateful to the court for recognizing his client’s innocence. “We hope this will bring the case to a close,” Phua's defense attorney Thomas Goldstein told AP. “The decision suppresses all the evidence that directly involves Mr. Phua.
